questions.text: If the Divisor of N is **4** and it gives a remainder equal to **3**, then find the value of **'N'** (Quotient = sum of the divisor and remainder).
questions.solution:
**Divisor** = 4
**Remainder** = 3
**Quotient** = 4 + 3 = 7
Using the Remainder Theorem:
$$\text{Dividend} = \text{Divisor} \times \text{Quotient} + \text{Remainder}$$
$$\text{Required N} = 4 \times 7 + 3 = 31$$

questions.text: If $$(x+5)$$ is divided by **6**, it gives remainder equal to $$(y+1)$$ and quotient comes equal to **half of the divisor**, then find the correct equation from the given options:
questions.solution:
$$\text{Dividend} = \text{Divisor} \times \text{Quotient} + \text{Remainder}$$
**Divisor** = 6
**Remainder** = $$y+1$$
**Quotient** = $$6/2 = 3$$
$$x + 5 = 6 \times 3 + y + 1$$
$$x + 5 = 18 + y + 1$$
$$x + 5 = 19 + y$$
$$x - y = 14$$

$$6452/4 \Rightarrow \text{remainder} = 0$$
$$2465/4 \Rightarrow \text{remainder} = 1$$
$$6898/4 \Rightarrow \text{remainder} = 2$$
$$2269/4 \Rightarrow \text{remainder} = 1$$
$$\text{Required} = (0+1+2+1)/4 \Rightarrow \text{remainder} = 0$$

questions.text:
If the value of $$(x+y+z)$$ is **9**, then the remainder when $$(A+B+C)$$ is divided by **6** is **3**. Which of the following is/are true?

**Additional information:**
(i) When we divide **'A'** by 6, we get the remainder equal to **'x'**.
(ii) When we divide **'B'** by 6, we get the remainder equal to **'y'**.
(iii) When we divide **'C'** by 6, we get the remainder equal to **'z'**.
questions.solution:
Based on the property of remainders, the remainder of the sum of numbers is equal to the remainder of the sum of their individual remainders.
$$\text{Sum of remainders} = x + y + z = 9$$
When 9 is divided by 6, the remainder is 3. Thus, all given conditions regarding the remainders of A, B, and C can be true.

questions.text: If $$(3x+y)$$ is divided by **9**, then the quotient comes is equal to **3**, then find the **highest possible value of 'x'** from the given options.
questions.solution:
$$\text{Dividend} = \text{Divisor} \times \text{Quotient} + \text{Remainder}$$
**Divisor** = 9, **Dividend** = $$3x+y$$, **Quotient** = 3
$$3x + y = 9 \times 3 + R$$
To find the highest value of $$x$$, we take the highest possible remainder $$R = 8$$.
$$3x + y = 27 + 8$$
$$3x + y = 35$$
$$x = (35 - y) / 3$$

questions.text: If we divide **63** by $$(x+5)$$ and remainder is equal to the **dividend**, then find the possible value of **'x'**: (Value of x is multiple of 10, x < 70).
questions.solution:
**Dividend** = 63
**Divisor** = $$x+5$$
**Remainder** = 63
In this case, the **divisor must be greater than the dividend** to leave the dividend itself as a remainder.
$$x + 5 > 63 \Rightarrow x > 58$$
Given $$x$$ is a multiple of 10 and $$x < 70$$, the possible value is **60**.

questions.text: Find the remainder of $$(13 \times 15 \times 18 \times 11)/8$$.
questions.solution:
$$13/8 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = 5$$
$$15/8 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = 7$$
$$18/8 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = 2$$
$$11/8 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = 3$$
$$\text{Required} = (5 \times 7 \times 2 \times 3)/8 = 210/8 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = 2$$

questions.text: If we divide **A, B, C and D by 4**, then we get the remainder equal to **'a', 'b', 'c' and 'd'** respectively. Which of the following is correct to find the value of **'K'**: (K is the remainder when we divide the **sum of a, b, c and d by 4**)?
questions.solution:
$$A/4 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = a$$
$$B/4 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = b$$
$$C/4 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = c$$
$$D/4 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = d$$
The remainder of the sum of numbers is equal to the remainder when the sum of their individual remainders is divided by the divisor.
$$\text{Required remainder K} = (a+b+c+d)/4$$

questions.text: If we divide **'x' by 17**, then we get the remainder equal to **4**, then to make the $$(x+y)$$ **completely divisible by 17**, find the value of **'y'** from the given options.
questions.solution:
If $$x$$ divided by 17 leaves remainder 4, then $$(x - 4)$$ is completely divisible by 17.
To make $$(x + y)$$ divisible by 17, we need to add a value to the remainder 4 such that the total equals 17.
$$4 + y = 17 \Rightarrow y = 13$$

questions.text: After dividing **64 by 13**, we get the remainder which is equal to **divisor of (x+5)**. In this case the remainder comes is equal to **9**, but if we **increase the divisor by 3**, then it gives **no remainder**. Find the possible value of **'x'** from the given options.
questions.solution:
$$\text{Divisor of } (x+5) = \text{Remainder of } 64/13 = 12$$
**Dividend** = $$x+5$$
**Remainder** = 9
**New divisor** = $$12 + 3 = 15$$
$$(x+5)$$ should be completely divisible by 15.
Checking options: If $$x = 40$$, then $$x + 5 = 45$$, which is divisible by 15.

questions.text: Find the remainder of $$(5^{10}/2)$$.
questions.solution:
We can write this as $$(5^2 \times 5^2 \times 5^2 \times 5^2 \times 5^2)/2$$.
Alternatively, using the rule: $$(5/2)$$ leaves remainder 1. 
Any power of 1 is 1.
$$\text{Remainder} = 1$$

questions.text: Find the remainder of $$(41^{648}/40)$$.
questions.solution:
If we divide 41 by 40 it gives remainder 1. 
Since the base 41 leaves remainder 1, any power of 41 divided by 40 will also leave remainder 1.
$$\text{Remainder} = 1$$

questions.text: Find the remainder of $$(80^{364}/81)$$.
questions.solution:
Using the property: $$\frac{a^{\text{even}}}{a+1}$$ always leaves a **remainder of 1**.
Here $$a = 80$$ and the power 364 is even.
$$\text{Remainder} = 1$$

questions.text: Find the remainder of $$(40^{645}/41)$$.
questions.solution:
Using the property: $$\frac{a^{\text{odd}}}{a+1}$$ always leaves a **remainder of 'a'**.
Here $$a = 40$$ and the power 645 is odd.
$$\text{Remainder} = 40$$

questions.text: If we divide **A by B**, we get the remainder **'r'**, then find the remainder when we divide **(A+A) by B**.
questions.solution:
$$A/B \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = r$$
$$(A + A)/B = (r + r)/B = 2r/B$$
If $$2r$$ is less than $$B$$, the remainder is $$2r$$. If $$2r$$ is greater than or equal to $$B$$, we divide again by $$B$$.

questions.text: The remainder comes when we divide **644 by 'X'** is **'R'**. Find the remainder when we divide **4508 by 'X'**.
questions.solution:
$$644/x \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = R$$
We can write 4508 as $$644 \times 7$$.
$$\frac{644 \times 7}{x} \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = 7R/X$$

questions.text: If we divide **'M' by 'D'**, then we get **65** as remainder. If we divide **5 times of M** by the same divisor, then the remainder comes is equal to **5**. Find the possible value of **'D'** from the given equations.
questions.solution:
$$M/D \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = 65$$
$$5M/D \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = (65 \times 5)/D = 325/D$$
Given that the final remainder is 5:
$$325 - 5 = 320$$
**D** must be a factor of 320 that is greater than the individual remainders.
Among the options, 16 is a factor of 320.

questions.text: If we divide **'K' by 645**, then we get the remainder as **5**. If we divide **4K by 645**, then the remainder is equal to:
questions.solution:
$$K/645 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = 5$$
$$4K/645 \Rightarrow \text{Remainder} = (4 \times 5)/645 = 20/645$$
$$\text{Remainder} = 20$$

questions.text: Radhika wants to distribute chocolates. She has total **640 chocolates** and total students in the class is $$(x+5)$$ (Excluding Radhika). Each student got **42 chocolates**, and the remaining chocolates left is **'x'**. Find the value of **'x'**.
questions.solution:
**Total chocolates** = 640
**Each student got** = 42
**Total students** = $$x+5$$
**Remaining** = $$x$$
Using Remainder formula: $$42(x + 5) + x = 640$$
$$42x + 210 + x = 640$$
$$43x = 430$$
$$x = 10$$

questions.text: Rajesh has total **24 sweaters** and he distributed them amongst **'x' people** such that each person gets equal number of sweaters. If after distribution Rajesh has **no sweater left**, then find the correct answer from the options:
questions.solution:
**Total sweaters** = 24
24 is completely divisible by $$x$$. 
Possible factors for $$x$$: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 24.
Checking option A: $$x + 2 = 10 \Rightarrow x = 8$$.
Since 24 is divisible by 8, option A is a valid combination.
